title: 5 Easy Ways to Charge Your iPad Without the Charging Block

steps.title: Find a USB-C or Lightning cable.
steps.content: Find a USB-C or Lightning cable. While you don't need a charging block to charge your iPad, you do need a charging cable. Depending on your iPad's model, you may need a Lightning cable or a USB-C cable. [1] X Research source Any Lightning or USB-C cable will work—including ones meant for an iPhone or even an Android phone!

steps.title: Plug it into your computer's USB port.
steps.content: Plug it into your computer's USB port. Your iPad should show that it's charging once you plug it in.

steps.title: Wait for the battery to charge.
steps.content: Wait for the battery to charge. iPads require a significant amount of power to charge, so fully charging your iPad can take a few hours using this method. Avoid using your iPad while it's charging to increase charging speed.

steps.title: Plug in your car charger.
steps.content: Plug in your car charger. You can either use a charger that plugs into your car's lighter port, or a USB cable if your car has USB ports. Depending on your iPad's model, you may need a Lightning cable or a USB-C cable.

steps.title: Connect your iPad via the charging cable.
steps.content: Connect your iPad via the charging cable. Your iPad should show that it's charging once you plug it in.

steps.title: Wait for it to charge.
steps.content: Wait for it to charge. It's best to charge devices while your car is running to avoid draining your car battery.

steps.title: Make sure your battery pack is charged.
steps.content: Make sure your battery pack is charged. Portable battery packs —also called power banks—allow you to charge your devices on the go and without plugging into a wall.

steps.title: Plug in your iPad using the USB cable.
steps.content: Plug in your iPad using the USB cable. Depending on your iPad's model, you may need a Lightning cable or a USB-C cable.

steps.title: Wait for it to charge.
steps.content: Wait for it to charge. External battery packs have different power ratings, and the charging time for devices varies accordingly. Use only Apple-certified accessories for your iPad to avoid any electrical damage. Keep your iPad turned off while it's plugged in so it charges faster.

steps.title: Find a public charging station.
steps.content: Find a public charging station. Most of the time, you'll find public charging stations at libraries or coffee shops. They may have a special charging station for devices, or they may simply offer USB slots on their tables or outlets that you can plug your USB charging cable directly into. Airports also usually have device charging stations, but you can only use them if you're inside the secure area of the airport. While public charging stations are handy, there is also a slight risk involved with using them, as it's possible for hackers to use malware to access your phone via charging stations. [2] X Trustworthy Source Federal Communications Commission Independent U.S. government agency responsible for regulating radio, television, and satellite, and phone communications Go to source To be completely safe, use a charging-only cable (not one that transmits data) and choose the option to "charge only" if asked to share data when you plug into a public charging station.

steps.title: Purchase a solar charger.
steps.content: Purchase a solar charger. If you are out and about often—especially in nature—it may not be convenient to have to stop and find a place to charge your device or to charge up a power bank. A solar charger (also called a solar power bank) can resolve these issues.

steps.title: Allow the solar charger to charge.
steps.content: Allow the solar charger to charge. Make sure to follow the instructions on your charger specifically, but you will need to charge it in sunlight.

steps.title: Plug your iPad into the solar charger.
steps.content: Plug your iPad into the solar charger. Note that it may take longer for a solar charger to charge up your iPad.
